answers.text: the mind starts blank, but acquires knowledge as the outside world is impressed upon it

qas.question: Whose ideas did Sextus build on?
What innate thoughts is a man born with?

context: This idea was later developed in ancient philosophy by the Stoic school. Stoic epistemology generally emphasized that <a0_0><b8_0>the mind starts blank<b8_0/>, but acquires knowledge as the outside world is impressed upon it<a0_0/>. The <a1_0><b7_0>doxographer<b7_0/><a1_0/> <a4_0><b9_0>Aetius<b9_0/><a4_0/> summarizes this view as "When a man is born, the Stoics say, he has the commanding part of his soul like a sheet of paper ready for writing upon." Later stoics, such as Sextus of <a2_0><b5_0>Chaeronea<b5_0/><a2_0/>, would continue this idea of empiricism in later Stoic writings as well. As <a3_0>Sextus<a3_0/> contends "For every thought comes from sense-perception or not without sense-perception and either from direct experience or not without direct experience" (<b6_0>Against the Professors<b6_0/>, 8.56-8).
